title: Housing Statistics for Modern Slavery Survivors

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
I am requesting information under the Freedom of Information Act 2000.
1. Do you ask any specific questions about modern slavery or human trafficking in the homelessness assessment?
2. If yes, what questions do you ask?
3. Please provide the number of people who made a homelessness application between August 1st 2023 to February 20th 2024 who were also recorded as victims of modern slavery with refugee status (either indefinite leave to remain or discretionary leave to remain).
4. Of this number, how many were considered to have a priority need for housing?
5. How many were not considered to have a priority need for housing?
Yours faithfully,
Helen Hodgson

Dear Helen Hodgson,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Housing Statistics
for Modern Slavery Survivors which we received on 13/03/2024.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
1. Do you ask any specific questions about modern slavery or human
trafficking in the homelessness assessment? Yes
2. If yes, what questions do you ask?
There are a set of questions we hask to ask all households who present as
homeless, these are a part of the statutory assessment that is set by
government. Some of these questions relate to support needs, one is ‘Are
you a victim of modern slavery’. We may not phrase a direct question to
the household exactly like that, our conversation with them about their
circumstances will inform if we enter yes or no. We would then record
follow up information relevant to their needs and circumstances, this will
vary from household to household.
3. Please provide the number of people who made a homelessness application
between August 1st 2023 to February 20th 2024 who were also recorded as
victims of modern slavery with refugee status (either indefinite leave to
remain or discretionary leave to remain).
55 households. Please note that this is a provisional figure which is
subject to quality assurance.
4. Of this number, how many were considered to have a priority need for
housing?
46 households have not yet had a priority need decision. 8 have been found
in priority need, 1 not in priority need.
5. How many were not considered to have a priority need for housing?
46 households have not yet had a priority need decision. 8 have been found
in priority need, 1 not in priority need.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains

licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your

If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you

for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council

Sheffield, S1 1UJ
